Covington & Burling LLP, an international law firm, responded to the committee’s subpoena requests on behalf of Columbia. The same firm helped prepare Shafik for her congressional testimony in April, the New York Times reported.

The committee requested communication records from individual trustees, including Wanda Holland Greene, who no longer serves on the board of trustees, Mark Gallogy, vice-chair of the board, and Shipman, co-chair of the board.

The letter from Covington & Burling requested that the committee keep the submitted documents confidential. Many documents included in the appendix are labeled as confidential at the bottom. A University spokesperson told Spectator that the University “did not consent” to the publication of the documents and that the committee provided Columbia with one day’s notice before publishing the report.

This table outlines the status of all disciplinary reports after April 18, the date of the first NYPD sweep of the “Gaza Solidarity Encampment.” Of the over 100 cases listed, most are related to the encampment or the Hamilton occupation.

This table includes disciplinary actions that were not released in the committee’s August report on Columbia’s disciplinary actions. The table includes all reports filed after Oct. 7, 2023. Many reports describe social media posts containing pro-Palestinian content by individual students that others found to be offensive. Some reports include names of individuals involved.

Barnard President Laura Rosenbury worked at Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP.

Barnard also requested that the committee keep the submitted materials confidential. A Barnard spokesperson told Spectator that the college did not consent to the publication of the materials.

Barnard submitted records of over 50 disciplinary actions pursued after Oct. 7, 2023.

An April 25 email shows Shafik’s reaction to a draft email that student organizers requested she send out to the Columbia community.

Murray wrote that she was “really uncomfortable” with Shafik agreeing to the draft that students had written.

Cobb served as a liaison between student organizers and administrators during the encampment negotiations.

In this document, dated April 27, CUAD submits counter-proposals to the concessions that Columbia offered to student organizers.

Student organizers pushed for greater financial transparency than the University initially offered—they asked for access to all of Columbia’s indirect holdings, including exchange-traded funds, private equity funds, and hedge funds.

CUAD organizers and administrators agreed that Shafik would issue a statement in support of academic freedom and establish a faculty committee on the topic.

Student organizers requested full, unconditional amnesty and did not want to sign attestations stating that they must comply with University policies until December 2024.

The University did not agree to issue any presidential statement drafted by student organizers, such as the one provided on Page 283.

The University requested that protesters dismantle the encampment within six hours of a final negotiation; CUAD requested 24 hours. CUAD also did not agree to the University’s request to not establish another encampment, writing that the decentralized nature of the coalition meant it was “beyond the control of CUAD.”

Days before the CUAD position paper, Shafik and trustees discussed a “menu” of potential responses to student organizers’ demands. Internal documents show that the University initially considered greater concessions than they presented to student organizers. Greenwald and Shipman, University Provost Angela Olinto, Secretary of the University Susan Glancy, and the Provost’s chief of staff Adina Brooks were all involved in these discussions.

It is unclear what iteration of the administrators’ menu of responses this document represents.

While administrators initially considered working with students on a draft statement, CUAD’s April 27 position paper showed that the University reneged after seeing a first draft.

The University considered establishing an interfaith center for Muslim students and other groups. Columbia has faced criticism for establishing an antisemitism task force but not explicitly addressing Islamophobia on campus.

The following document is a testimony from an anonymous individual on disciplinary processes in the University Senate. It includes proposed solutions for adjudicating future violations.

Source: Spectator reporting, House Committee on Education and The Workforce

Source: House Committee on Education and The Workforce,

Spectator reporting

Graphic by Ayaan Ali

Covington & Burling LLP, an international law firm, responded to the committee’s subpoena requests on behalf of Columbia. The same firm helped prepare Shafik for her congressional testimony in April, the New York Times reported.

The committee requested communication records from individual trustees, including Wanda Holland Greene, who no longer serves on the board of trustees, Mark Gallogy, vice-chair of the board, and Shipman, co-chair of the board.

The letter from Covington & Burling requested that the committee keep the submitted documents confidential. Many documents included in the appendix are labeled as confidential at the bottom. A University spokesperson told Spectator that the University “did not consent” to the publication of the documents and that the committee provided Columbia with one day’s notice before publishing the report.

This table outlines the status of all disciplinary reports after April 18, the date of the first NYPD sweep of the “Gaza Solidarity Encampment.” Of the over 100 cases listed, most are related to the encampment or the Hamilton occupation.

This table includes disciplinary actions that were not released in the committee’s August report on Columbia’s disciplinary actions. The table includes all reports filed after Oct. 7, 2023. Many reports describe social media posts containing pro-Palestinian content by individual students that others found to be offensive. Some reports include names of individuals involved.

Barnard President Laura Rosenbury worked at Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP.

Barnard also requested that the committee keep the submitted materials confidential. A Barnard spokesperson told Spectator that the college did not consent to the publication of the materials.

Barnard submitted records of over 50 disciplinary actions pursued after Oct. 7, 2023.

An April 25 email shows Shafik’s reaction to a draft email that student organizers requested she send out to the Columbia community.

Murray wrote that she was “really uncomfortable” with Shafik agreeing to the draft that students had written.

Cobb served as a liaison between student organizers and administrators during the encampment negotiations.

In this document, dated April 27, CUAD submits counter-proposals to the concessions that Columbia offered to student organizers.

Student organizers pushed for greater financial transparency than the University initially offered—they asked for access to all of Columbia’s indirect holdings, including exchange-traded funds, private equity funds, and hedge funds.

CUAD organizers and administrators agreed that Shafik would issue a statement in support of academic freedom and establish a faculty committee on the topic.

Student organizers requested full, unconditional amnesty and did not want to sign attestations stating that they must comply with University policies until December 2024.

The University did not agree to issue any presidential statement drafted by student organizers, such as the one provided on Page 283.

The University requested that protesters dismantle the encampment within six hours of a final negotiation; CUAD requested 24 hours. CUAD also did not agree to the University’s request to not establish another encampment, writing that the decentralized nature of the coalition meant it was “beyond the control of CUAD.”

Days before the CUAD position paper, Shafik and trustees discussed a “menu” of potential responses to student organizers’ demands. Internal documents show that the University initially considered greater concessions than they presented to student organizers. Greenwald and Shipman, University Provost Angela Olinto, Secretary of the University Susan Glancy, and the Provost’s chief of staff Adina Brooks were all involved in these discussions.

It is unclear what iteration of the administrators’ menu of responses this document represents.

While administrators initially considered working with students on a draft statement, CUAD’s April 27 position paper showed that the University reneged after seeing a first draft.

The University considered establishing an interfaith center for Muslim students and other groups. Columbia has faced criticism for establishing an antisemitism task force but not explicitly addressing Islamophobia on campus.

The following document is a testimony from an anonymous individual on disciplinary processes in the University Senate. It includes proposed solutions for adjudicating future violations.

Source: Spectator reporting, House Committee on Education and The Workforce
